body_html:
Hi @assasins353. I'm not sure why conda would warn you that installing from source is better. Anyway, you can certainly install TensorFlow from source or through conda. Neither of which are recommended.

For conda, TensorFlow 1.8.0 is provided in the conda-forge channel. You can install TensorFlow 1.8.0 by conda install -c conda-forge tensorflow==1.8.0.

Now, if you are trying to install TensorFlow with pip in a conda environment, this may cause issues. I noticed when I had two versions of TensorFlow (one install through pip, and the other through conda) that the conda installation would take precendent over the pip installation. This means that tf.__version__ would return the version installed through conda.

It's easy to avoid all this by creating virtual environments. Follow the recommended TensorFlow installation documentation. If you want to install TensorFlow from source and with conda, you should create a virtual environment for the source installation. See the virtualenv documentation to create a virtual environment. The other could be kept in your main base conda environment.

For future reference, please direct these types of questions to StackOverflow.

body:
Hi @assasins353. I'm not sure why `conda` would warn you that installing from source is better. Anyway, you can certainly install TensorFlow from source or through `conda`. Neither of which are recommended. 

For `conda`, TensorFlow 1.8.0 is provided in the `conda-forge` channel. You can install TensorFlow 1.8.0 by `conda install -c conda-forge tensorflow==1.8.0`. 

Now, if you are trying to install TensorFlow with `pip` in a `conda` environment, this may cause issues. I noticed when I had two versions of TensorFlow (one install through pip, and the other through conda) that the conda installation would take precendent over the pip installation. This means that `tf.__version__` would return the version installed through `conda`. 

It's easy to avoid all this by creating virtual environments. Follow the recommended [TensorFlow installation documentation](https://www.tensorflow.org/install/). If you want to install TensorFlow from source and with `conda`, you should create a virtual environment for the source installation. See the [virtualenv documentation](https://virtualenv.pypa.io/en/stable/userguide/) to create a virtual environment. The other could be kept in your main base conda environment.

**For future reference, please direct these types of questions to [StackOverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/).**
